instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2523: What is 820-2523? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> present, all s5 power rails present
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B NO <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> PRESENT, ALL S5 POWER RAILS PRESENT
IDK WHAT TO DO FROM HERE,

green light (yes)
charges battery idk
i also believe that vr pwrgd delay was 0v as well
idk what im missing/where to go from here. i tried finding a short but no luck
*bought from ebay to practice on, previous owner changed bios chip and knocked off a few resistors, i replaced the bios chip (preprogrammed off internet) and resistors (donor board)
and i also had to replace <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> on ppcdin,
any ideas on where to go from here.
i saw <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> comes from the mcp, i believe i tested the s5 rails coming into that chip ( i only saw 2) and they were present. [TABLE="border: 0, cellpadding: 0, cellspacing: 0"]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> present, all s5 power rails present
threads.message: A common issue with this boards is <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>, check voltage on L7770 should be 1V......

threads.message: both sides of l7771 were 1.05v

resistance to ground on 3v42 is.....(measured on <CAPACITOR>C5725</CAPACITOR>, diode mode .636, 20.94 kohm measured as well)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> present, all s5 power rails present
threads.message: You have to have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> for this machine to turn on. this is not a fun one to work on. when i see these i first check all the power rails from the beginning to make sure i didn't mis something. if all is good, then i check the area around the smc, also checking for sort to ground on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>, las one i did had some crap under the smc i had to reflow the smc.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> present, all s5 power rails present
threads.message: ok thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> present, all s5 power rails present
threads.message: You are using an ORIGINAL 85W charger? No chinese garbage or anything below 85W will power this board!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> present, all s5 power rails present
threads.message: You should also spend a solid 10 minutes looking over the board and making SURE there are no missing components, or any small caps/resistors that have been knocked off the board. If you got this from eBay, it's probably been tossed around in its life...might have some missing bits.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> present, all s5 power rails present
threads.message:
the charger is original, and i did inspect the board for missing components, everytime i saw a spot that looked like it might need something it was an omit or no stuff spot. 
ill check the smc and the area around it, and check slp s4 for a short, thanks
